info.game_comments:
Barbara-Anne Eddy game 5.
Final Jeopardy! logo flashes on the game board's monitors instead of the show's logo.

(1, 1).clue: The man Simple Simon met could have sold him one of these

(2, 1).clue: To gloss over reading material, or to remove fat from milk

(4, 1).clue: After being wounded in Revolutionary War battle of Trenton, he probably needed some doctrine

(5, 1).clue: The stevedores here, in West Germany's busiest port, must be really beefy

(6, 1).clue: While a variable is a quantity that changes, this is the term for a quantity that stays the same

(1, 2).clue: A litchi is commonly referred to as one

(2, 2).clue: From the Latin "par" meaning equal, it's your equal on a jury

(4, 2).clue: The Iranians held the U.S. embassy hostages until he left office

(5, 2).clue: This city didn't rise from its ashes like its namesake, but from the Salt River Valley

(6, 2).clue: (Video Daily Double)In science the meaning of the following ion symbols:[+ - ]

(1, 3).clue: When used alone, this grain produces a black bread like pumpernickel

(2, 3).clue: Kipling said you'll be a man "if you can keep" this "when all about you are losing theirs"

(4, 3).clue: Like Coolidge before him, he was sworn in by former president Taft

(5, 3).clue: The name of this Scottish city, 3rd largest in Great Britain, is said to be from the Celtic for "dear green spot"

(6, 3).clue: While the smallest unit of an element is an atom, the smallest unit of a compound is this

(1, 4).clue: The coco yam, a west African variety of taro, can also be used to make this Pacific island dish

(2, 4).clue: 1 of 2 past tense forms of "go" that fit the category

(4, 4).clue: His administration created the National Security Council, which was in the news a lot in 1987

(5, 4).clue: This city in Nova Scotia is the Atlantic terminus of Canada's 2 major railways

(6, 4).clue: Its mechanical heart is not a Jarvik-7, but a CPU, or central processing unit

(1, 5).clue: Legend says Columbus brought this vegetable to the New World in 1493

(2, 5).clue: German for "stop", it'll also stop a troop of American soldiers

(4, 5).clue: Among the White House renovations he made was cleaning out Garfield's cabinet

(5, 5).clue: As Iran & Iraq have 4 letters, these cities, their capitals, both have 7, as usually spelled in English

(6, 5).clue: The unit of measure for this force is the bar or millibar

(1, 1).clue: It's said the Amazon basin provides the Earth with about 1/5 of this element that makes up 1/5 of the air

(2, 1).clue: In Bellini's "I Capuleti e I Montecchi", this famous pair is sung by a soprano & a mezzo-soprano

(3, 1).clue: It's what's counted by the ream

(5, 1).clue: Published when he was 72, his last book was on earthworms, not natural selection

(6, 1).clue: A popular saying with soldiers in WWI was "50 million" of these "can't be wrong"

(1, 2).clue: Also called the cream nut, or butternut, it's the seed of an evergreen found mainly in the Amazon basin

(2, 2).clue: Leoncavallo wasn't clowning around when he wrote this, his 1st produced opera & only hit

(4, 2).clue: The Roman emperor Constantine I left Rome & made this city the capital

(5, 2).clue: Reportedly the oldest working playwright ever, this author of "Saint Joan" wrote his last play at age 93

(6, 2).clue: In geography, number of minutes in 1 degree

(1, 3).clue: This part of the Amazon is so large that Marajo, an island almost the size of Denmark, lies within it

(2, 3).clue: Long before the play "Amadeus", this hyphenated Russian wrote the opera "Mozart & Salieri"

(3, 3).clue: U.S. standard unit equal to .083 foot

(4, 3).clue: Term for the order maintained by the Roman Empire in its part of the world from 27 B.C. to 180 A.D.

(5, 3).clue: Physician & writer of the 3rd Gospel, he lived to be 84

(6, 3).clue: If a waitress complains her customers just did a 95, it means they did this

(1, 4).clue: Large scale use of the Amazon's vast rubber crop was made possible by this process, invented in 1839

(2, 4).clue: Mimi was a seamstress in this Puccini opera

(3, 4).clue: Of a gross ton, a net ton, or a short ton, the one not equal to either of the others

(4, 4).clue: 5th man to reign as emperor & last to bear family name "Caesar"

(5, 4).clue: Execs who feared offending this 78-year-old publisher offered RKO $800,000 to scrap "Citizen Kane"

(6, 4).clue: Famous phrase describing the number of years between 1776 & 1863

(2, 5).clue: 5 of the 9 were Waltraute, Helmwige, Schwertleite, Grimgerde & Brunnhilde

(3, 5).clue: As defined, a periodical is published at regular intervals greater than this period of time

(4, 5).clue: Julius Caesar was killed not in the Senate chamber but in a theater built by this rival of his

(5, 5).clue: Advisor to Lincoln, this ex-slave became U.S. minister to Haiti at age 72

(6, 5).clue: The U.N. picked Matej Gaspar, born July 11, 1987, to symbolize this numerical achievement of our species

(0, 0).clue: Pen name of veterinarian James Alfred Wight
